name: costing or worth little or no money

children.name: free
children.definition: /friː/  allowed or able to do what you want, without being restricted by rules or by other people:
examples: tự do
▪ I had just left home, and was enjoying the feeling of being free and independent at last.
Tôi vừa mới rời khỏi nhà, và cuối cùng cũng được tận hưởng cảm giác tự do và độc lập.
free to do something
tự do được làm gì
▪ During ‘Golden Time’, the pupils are free to choose the activity they would like to do.
Suốt 'Thời gian Vàng', học sinh được tự do chọn hoạt động mà họ muốn làm.
freeadjective,adverbNO CHARGE miễnphí
costing nothing; not needing to be paid for
_I got some free cinema tickets.
_Members all receive a free copy of the monthly newsletter.
_The elderly travel free on public transport.
_We will install your washing machine freeof charge/forfree (= without charge) .

children.name: cost nothing/not cost anything
children.definition: cost nothing/ not cost anything/ˌkɒst ˈnʌθɪŋ, ˌnɒt kɒst ˈeniθɪŋǁˌkɔːst-/  to be free:
examples: không tốn một xu nào
▪ Luckily I was insured, so the treatment didn’t cost anything.
May là tôi được bảo hiểm, nên việc điều trị không tốn của tôi một xu nào.
cost nothing/ not cost anything to do something
khống tốn tiền
▪ It doesn’t cost anything to get advice from them.
Tôi không phải tốn tiền để được họ tư vấn.
▪ The competition costs nothing to enter, just send a postcard with your name and address.
Cuộc thi không tính tiền vào cửa, chỉ cần gửi một tấm bưu thiếp ghi tên và địa chỉ của mình.

children.name: for nothing X/for free
children.definition: for nothing/for free/fəʳ ˈnʌθɪŋ, fəʳ ˈfriː/  without having to pay for something that you would normally have to pay for:
examples: miễn phí
▪ He offered to fix the car for nothing.
Anh ta yêu cầu được sửa xe miễn phí.
▪ Fans were allowed into the stadium for nothing as a way of celebrating.
Người hâm mộ được phép vào sân vận động miễn phí như một hình thức chúc mừng.
▪ Children under five can see the show for free.
Trẻ em dưới 5 tuổi có thể xem buổi diễn miễn phí.
for nothing
free or without paying
_I got this picture for nothing from a friend.

children.name: free of charge U
children.definition: free of charge /ˌfriː əv ˈtʃɑːʳdʒ/  without having to pay - used especially in advertisements and official notices:
examples: miễn phí
▪ Guests can park free of charge all day.
Qúy khách có thể đậu xe miễn phí cả ngày.
▪ Copies of the leaflet can be obtained free of charge from your local library.
Những bản sao tờ rơi có thể có được miễn phí từ thư viện gần nhà bạn.
▪ This policy ensures that you get emergency medical treatment free of charge when travelling abroad.
Chính sách này đảm bảo việc bạn được nhận sự điều trị y tế khẩn cấp miễn phí khi du lịch ở nước ngoài.

children.name: no charge
children.definition: /ˌnəʊ ˈtʃɑːʳdʒ/  if there is no charge for aservicethat someone provides, you do not have to pay for it:
examples: miễn phí
▪ ‘How much is the prescription?’ ‘No charge -- students are exempt from payment.’
'Đơn thuốc bao nhiêu tiền thế?' 'Miễn phí - học sinh được miễn phí'.
▪ Entry to the museum costs £3, but there is no charge on Wednesdays and Sundays.
Phí vào cửa của viện bảo tàng là £ 3, nhưng vào các ngày thứ Tư và Chủ nhật thì miễn phí.
no charge for
không phải trả tiền
▪ There is no charge for cashing these travellers’ cheques.
Không phải trả tiền mặt cho séc du lịch.

children.name: be on the house
children.definition: /biː ˌɒn ðə ˈhaʊs/  if drinks or meals are on the house, they are given to you by the owner of the bar or restaurant that you are in and you do not have to pay for them:
examples: được chiêu đãi (bởi chủ tiệm)
▪ On New Year’s Eve, he offered a glass of champagne to everyone, on the house.
Vào đêm giao thừa, anh ấy chiêu đãi mỗi người một ly sâm-panh, miễn phí.
▪ The owner let us have the first bottle of wine on the house.
Vị chủ tiệm lần đàu tiên chiêu đãi chúng tôi một chai rượu miễn phí.

children.name: at no cost to sb
children.definition: at no cost to somebody/ət ˌnəʊ ˈkɒst tə somebody ǁ-ˈkɔːst-/  if a service is provided at no cost to someone, they do not have to pay for it:
examples: miễn phí
▪ The Helpline provides advice on all types of personal problems at no cost to the caller.
Đường dây hỗ trợ đưa ra lời khuyên về mọi lĩnh vực vấn đề cá nhân miễn phí cho người gọi.
▪ Treatment at the health center is available at no cost to students.
Sự điều ở trung tâm sức khỏe luôn có sẵn và miễn phí cho học sinh.

children.name: gratis
children.definition: /ˈgrætɪs, ˈgrætəs, ˈgreɪts/  especiallywrittenprovided without payment:
examples: không phải trả tiền
▪ His work for the church is performed gratis.
Anh ấy làm việc cho nhà thờ mà không cần được trả lương.
▪ You can see some local bands at local clubs absolutely gratis.
Bạn có thể thấy những nhóm nhạc trong vùng ở những câu lạc bộ trong vùng đều không cần được trả tiền.

children.name: at no extra cost
children.definition: /ət ˌnəʊ ekstrə ˈkɒstǁ-ˈkɔːst/  if a shop or a company provides an additional service at no extra cost, they do it without asking you for any more money:
examples: khuyến mãi
▪ Many activities are available at the hotel at no extra cost, but theatre trips and excursions are not included.
Có rất nhiều hoạt động khuyến mãi có sẵn tại khách sạn, nhưng không bao gồm chuyến đi tới nhà hát hay chuyến tham quan.
at no extra cost to
khuyến mãi cho ai
▪ The store is offering to install satellite dishes at no extra cost to the buyer.
Cửa hàng xin được lắp đặt đĩa vệ tinh miễn phí cho người mua hàng.

children.name: cheap
children.definition: /tʃiːp/  something that is cheap costs very little money, or costslessthanyou expected:
examples: ▪ My shoes were really cheap - they only cost $15.
▪ The cheapest way to get to Chicago is to take the bus.
it is cheap to do something
▪ It’s cheaper to phone after six o'clock.
relatively cheapcheap compared with other things
▪ Wooden houses are relatively cheap to build.
cheaply[adverb]
▪ You can buy electronic diaries fairly cheaply nowadays.
cheapadjectiveLOW PRICE giá thấp; ít tốn tiền; rẻ
costing little money or less than is usual or expected
_I got a cheap flight at the last minute.
_Food is usually cheaper in supermarkets.
_Children and the elderly are entitled to cheap train tickets.
_The scheme is simple and cheaptooperate.
_During times of mass unemployment, there's
a pool of cheaplabourfor employers to draw from.
_figurativeIn a war, human life becomes very cheap (= seems to be of little value) .

children.name: inexpensive
children.definition: /ˌɪnɪkˈspensɪv◂/  not expensive - use this especially about things that are ofgoodquality, even though they do not cost a lot:
examples: không mắc
▪ The furniture is inexpensive but well-made.
▪ a simple, inexpensive meal
▪ Beans and lentils are an inexpensive source of protein.
relativelyinexpensivenot expensive compared to something similar
▪ a hotel that offers air-conditioned rooms at relatively inexpensive prices
inexpensiveadjective không đắt, rẻ
not costing a lot of money
_It's an inexpensive perfume.

children.name: economical
children.definition: cheap to use or cheap to do - use this about cars, machines, or ways of doing things that do not waste money, fuel etc: kinh tế , tiết kiệm
examples: ▪ We have a very economical heating system, so the bills aren’t too high.
What's the most economical way of heating this building?
be economical to use/run/operate
▪ This is a well-designed car that is also very economical to run.
it is more economical to do something
▪ It’s more economical to buy the big packet - it’s only 50p more than the small one.
economical on sth
There's increasing demand for cars which are more economicalonfuel.

children.name: not cost much
children.definition: /nɒt ˈkɒst ˌmʌtʃǁ-ˈkɔːst-/  especiallyspokento not be expensive:
examples: không mắc lắm
▪ We stayed in a very nice hotel in Vienna and it didn’t cost much.
it doesn’t cost much to do something
▪ It doesn’t cost much to rent an apartment here.

children.name: affordable
children.definition: /əˈfɔːʳdəbəl/  cheap enough for most people to be able to buy:
examples: ▪ Single mothers often have trouble finding affordable child care.
▪ We have a vast range of cars to choose from at affordable prices.
affordableadjective phải chăng, vừa phải
not expensive
_nice clothes at affordable prices

children.name: low-cost
children.definition: /ˌləʊ ˈkɒst◂ǁ-ˈkɔːst◂/  low-cost housing/heating/transport etc intended to be cheap to use, buy, rent etc:
examples: ▪ If you want low-cost transport and regular exercise, a bike is ideal.
▪ If elected, he promised to build more low-cost housing in the city.
▪ The US is giving low-cost loans to help under-developed countries in the region.

children.name: be low in price
children.definition: /biː ˌləʊ ɪn ˈpraɪs/  especially written if a product is low in price, it is cheap to buy:
examples: ▪ Nikon’s latest camera is low in price and easy to use.
▪ The ‘Pocket-Pack’ range of toys are very low in price and will provide hours of pleasure for the kids.

children.name: low-budget
children.definition: /ˌləʊ ˈbʌdʒt◂/  low-budget film/movie/ production etc one that has been made very cheaply:
examples: ▪ My first acting job was in a low-budget horror movie with a terrible plot.

children.name: budget
children.definition: /ˈbʌdʒɪt, ˈbʌdʒət/ budget hotel/flight/accommodation etcbudget hotels, flights etc are very low in price:
examples: ▪ The Tourist Information Office will give you a list of budget hotels in the area.
budgetadjective[ before noun ] rẻ, không đắt tiền
very cheap
_a budget holiday/hotel/price

children.name: it won’t break the bank
children.definition: /ɪt ˌwəʊnt breɪk ðə ˈbæŋk/ spoken use this to say that you have enough money to buy or do something, and you should buy or do it:
examples: ▪ ‘I’m not sure if I should buy this suit.’ ‘Come on! It won’t break the bank!’
without breaking the bankwithout having to pay a lot of money
▪ This guide lists 900 of the best places in which to eat without breaking the bank.

children.name: modest
children.definition: adjectiveNOT LARGE vừa phải, phải chăng
examples: not expensive
_They live in a fairly modest house, considering their wealth.
_There has been a modest improvement/recovery in housing conditions for the poor.
_The party made modest gains in the elections, but nothing like the huge gains that were predicted.
_Just a modest portion for me, please.

children.name: sth that is given free by a company
complimentary
children.definition: /ˌkɒmplɪˈmentəri◂, ˌkɒmpləˈmentəri◂ǁˌkɑːm-/  use this about things that a company, theatre, hotel etc gives people for free:
examples: miễn phí
▪ Karen’s sister works at the New York Ballet and she’s managed to get us some complimentary tickets.
Chị gái của Karen làm việc tại nhà hát New York Ballet nên cô ấy có thể cho chúng ta vài tấm vé miễn phí.
▪ Honeymooners receive a complimentary bottle of champagne in their hotel room.
Các cặp đôi đang hưởng tuần trăng mật sẽ được nhận một chai rượu sâm-panh miễn phí trong phòng khách sạn.
complimentaryadjectiveFREE mời;biếu (vé)
If tickets, books, etc. are complimentary, they are given free, especially by a business.

children.name: free gift
children.definition: /ˌfriː ˈgɪft/  something that is given free by a shop or a company, especially in order to advertise its products or to encourage you to buy something else:
examples: quà tặng miễn phí
▪ Buy three skincare products and you can choose your super free gift.
Hãy mua 3 sản phẩm dưỡng da và bạn có thể chọn cho mình một quà tặng miễn phí siêu khủng.
▪ We came back from the tour round the factory loaded down with free gifts.
Chúng tôi quay lại sau khi dạo quanh nhà máy với nhiều quà tặng miễn phí.

children.name: freebie
children.definition: /ˈfriːbiː/  informal something a company gives free with its products, or gives to the people it employs:
examples: quà tặng
▪ ‘Where did you get that calendar?’ ‘It was a freebie from work.’
"Bạn có tấm lịch đó ở đâu thế?" "Đó là quà tặng từ chỗ làm."
▪ Most airlines offer freebies to children traveling on their planes.
Hầu hết các hãng hàng không tặng quà miễn phí cho trẻ em đi trên máy bay của họ.

children.name: cheap
children.definition: /tʃiːp/  something that is cheap does not cost much, and is clearly ofbadquality:
examples: rẻ tiền
▪ The tourist shops were full of cheap souvenirs.
▪ The hotel room was very small, with cheap furniture and a bumpy bed.
▪ Oh look -- a present from Rob. I bet it’s another bottle of cheap perfume.

children.name: cheap and nasty
children.definition: /ˌtʃiːp ən ˈnɑːstiǁ-ˈnæs-/  British furniture, jewellery, or clothes that are cheap and nasty look cheap and of very bad quality:
examples: rẻ tiền
▪ What do you think of these bracelets? They look really cheap and nasty to me.
▪ I don’t like plastic shoes. They always seem cheap and nasty.

children.name: when you get sth for a good price
be a good value
children.definition: be good value/biː ˌgʊd ˈvæljuː/  to be worth the price that you pay, especially a price that is not high:
examples: xứng đáng với đồng tiền bỏ ra, giá phải chăng
▪ The meals at Charlie’s Pizza are really good value.
be a good valueAmerican
▪ The CD-ROM encyclopedia is a good value because the printed encyclopedia set sells for twice as much.

children.name: be a good buy
children.definition: /biː ə ˌgʊd ˈbaɪ/  something that is a good buy is worth the price you pay for it, because it isnotexpensivebut is stillgood:
examples: món hàng đáng mua
▪ The Brazilian white wine is a good buy at only $2.99 a bottle.
▪ College officials insist that higher education is a good buy despite rising tuition costs.

children.name: bargain
children.definition: /ˈbɑːʳgɪn, ˈbɑːʳgən/  something that costs a lot less than you expect or a lot less than it usually costs:
examples: món hời
▪ Did you get any bargains at the market?
▪ I got this shirt when I was in Indonesia. It was a real bargain.
bargainnoun[ C ]LOW PRICE món hời
something on sale at a lower price than its true value
_This coat was half-price - a real bargain.
_The airline regularly offers last-minute bookings at bargainprices.
_The sales had started and the bargainhunters(= people looking for things at a low price) were out in force.

children.name: value for money
children.definition: /ˌvæljuː fəʳ ˈmʌni/  especially British if something that is being sold is value for money, it is worth the price that you pay -use this about something that isfairlycheap but is of areasonablestandardorquality:
examples: đáng với đồng tiền bỏ ra
be (good) value for money
▪ Sainsbury’s cookbooks are generally considered to be value for money.
▪ There’s a special ticket that means you can see six concerts, which is definitely good value for money.
get value for moneyget something that is worth the price you paid
mua được món xứng đáng với đồng tiền bỏ ra
▪ The show was less than one hour long and we didn’t really get value for money.

children.name: a good deal
children.definition: /ə ˌgʊd ˈdiːl/  if something is a good deal, it is worth the price you pay, because it includes a lot of additional things or services:
examples: be a good/excellent/great etc deal
▪ The price of the holiday includes free use of the tennis courts, the pool, and the gym. It’s a very good deal.
give somebody a good deal
▪ They gave me a really good deal on my camera.get a good deal
▪ Cowpland said he was willing to buy the company if he got a good deal.

children.name: worthless
children.definition: /ˈwɜːʳθləs/
examples: ▪ When he died, all my uncle left me was a worthless plot of land.
▪ The jewellery turned out to be completely worthless.
▪ I’m afraid this banknote is a forgery; it’s just a worthless piece of paper.
worthlessadjectiveNO MONEY vô giá trị
having no value in money
_The company's shares are nowvirtuallyworthless shares.
_He said the jewels were worthless fakes.

children.name: valueless
children.definition: adjectiveNO MONEY không đáng giá
examples: not worth any money
_We thought the chair was an antique worth a lot
of money, but it turned out to be a valueless replica.

children.name: not be worth anything
children.definition: /nɒt biː ˈwɜːʳθ ˌeniθɪŋ/  to have no value:
examples: ▪ I don’t think my stereo is worth anything now, but it was quite expensive when I bought it.

children.name: half-price
children.definition: adjective,adverb nửa giá bình thường
examples: costing half the usual price
_I got some half-price pizzas at the supermarket.
_The railcard allows students and young people to travel half-price on most trains.

children.name: not too expensive when compared to other prices
reasonable
children.definition: hợp lí , phải chăng
examples: reasonable/ˈriːzənəbəl/ [adjective] reasonable prices seem fair because they are not too high:
▪ They sell good-quality computer equipment at reasonable prices.
▪ Only £15 a night? That sounds reasonable.
reasonableadjective
3. not too expensive
Tomatoes are very reasonable at this time of year.

children.name: competitive
children.definition: /kəmˈpetɪtɪv, kəmˈpetətɪv/  as low as or lower than the prices charged by other shops or companies:
examples: cạnh trạnh
▪ I think you’ll find our prices are extremely competitive.
▪ The hotel offers a high standard of service at very competitive rates.
competitively priced/kəmˌpetɪtɪvli ˈpraɪst, kəmˌpetətɪvli ˈpraɪst/ [adjective phrase]
▪ Call this number for our free catalogue of competitively priced software.

children.name: reasonably
children.definition: adverb vừa phải; chấp nhận được
examples: at a price which is not too expensive
_You can eat out very reasonably these days.
_I bought a reasonablypricedradio.

children.name: dirt cheap
children.definition: /ˌdɜːʳt ˈtʃiːp◂/  informal extremely cheap:
examples: ▪ You can get beautiful leather jackets in the markets and they’re dirt cheap.
dirt cheap[adverb]
▪ She buys all her clothes dirt cheap in charity shops.

children.name: be a snip/steal
children.definition: be a snip/biː ə ˈsnɪp/ Britishinformal/be asteal/biː ə ˈstiːl/ American informal  to be extremely cheap at a particular price:
examples: ▪ She says her new outfit was a steal.
▪ The new computer package is a snip at only £599 plus tax.

children.name: at rockbottom prices
children.definition: /ət ˌrɒkbɒtəm ˈpraɪszǁˌrɑːkbɑː-/ also at giveaway prices /ət ˈgɪvəweɪ ˌpraɪsz/ British  if a shop is selling goods at rockbottom prices or at giveaway prices, it is selling them at extremely low prices -- used especially in advertisements:
examples: ▪ Fox Hi-Fi specialize in selling top quality CD players at rockbottom prices.
▪ In our summer sale, we have clothes from top designers at giveaway prices.

children.name: for very little money
children.definition: /fəʳ ˌveri lɪtl ˈmʌni/
examples: ▪ You can pick up video recorders for very little money if you know where to look.

children.name: for nothing
children.definition: /fəʳ ˈnʌθɪŋ/  especially American very cheaply:
examples: ▪ We got the car for nothing because the woman wanted to get rid of it fast.

children.name: miserable
children.definition: adjectiveLOW VALUE tồi tàn, nghèo nàn
examples: [ before noun ]having little value or quality
_informalShe only offered me a miserable £20 for my old computer.
_slangSome miserable bastard went and vandalised my car.

children.name: with your compliments
children.definition: withyourcomplimentsformal
examples: If you give something to someone with your compliments, you give it to them free
_We enclose a copy of our latest brochure, with our compliments.
